newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysian couple face 2,372 charges over cheques.
newsitem.headline: Malaysian couple face 2,372 charges over cheques.

text.p: A Malaysian businessman and his wife may have set a record of sorts when they sat through a marathon seven-hour court reading of 2,372 charges for alleged cheque forgery.
The case involving cheques valued at 9.3 million ringgit ($3.72 million) was heard in Sibu Sessions Court in east Malaysia's Sarawak state on Wednesday, the New Straits Times reported on Thursday.
It took seven hours for three interpreters, defence and prosecution officials to read out the 2,372 charges and have the couple's pleas of not guilty recorded separately.
The interpreters were necessary because defendants are ethnic Chinese and court proceedings are conducted in Malay.

Ling Sui Ngee is accused of assisting in disposing of the cheques which his wife Hu Siew Hie, a former employee of timber firm Rimbunan Hijau Group, allegedly forged. The offences allegedly occurred between 1994 and 1996 and carry a penalty of 20-year jail terms and a fine upon conviction.
The couple's trial is fixed for December 1.
The Sibu court had to postpone all other cases set for Wednesday to deal with the marathon hearing, the newspaper said.
